I think you are a bit too optimistic. Perhaps very few are talking explicitly about the deficit, but it and related concerns loom very large over all aspects of policy debates. It's still why we can have federal stimulus spending, infrastructure investments, or any kinds of tax increases at the state or federal level. And many, if not all, of the states have greatly ratcheted down their spending and investments. The downward pressure may be off, but we have moved to what many call, "the new normal".

One form of interpersonal racism may may no longer be common, since people are less prone than they were to express their slurs and insults one-on-one.

But since President Obama's election and reelection, I believe that third-person racism, coded and even more explicit, has become more commonplace in conversation. And it's become all the more acceptable because because it's expressed all the time without embarrassment from public figures of the political right, frequently with the President himself as the target.

As for systemic racism, I believe that that it is a convenient proxy for classism. The privileged around the world try to maintain their advantage by the tactic of divide and conquer, pitting the rest of the people against each other; if race is not a factor, something else like religion or language works equally well.

So systemic racism would lessen, if not go away, if we could tackle the winner-take-all economy.

What, me disagree?

You missed a key point made in the editorial -- that most of the fast growing jobs are for lower-skilled workers. e.g. retail, services, home health aide, etc.. These jobs can not be outsourced to China. So actually people with lower education levels should be able to find a job.

Also, what is your data source for education level and fertility rate? According to the Population Reference Bureau, the fertility rate is 1.8 for white women, 1.7 for Asian women, 2.0 for Black women and 2.4 for Hispanic women. These are not dramatically big differences, nor do they indicate very big families.
http://www.prb.org/Publications/Datasheets/2012/world-population-data-sh...

CM, unemployment is much higher among poorly-skilled than highly-skilled workers. Furthermore, their wages are depressed. That will not change as things now stand, because the elevation of workers into the middle income group depended on the productivity of factory production and unionization, both of which have been victims of globalization and the de facto integration of a vast pool of low-wage foreign workers into the workforce.

Also, you seem to be confusing ethnicity with educational attainment. The actual figures are shocking and, given our demonstrated inability to increase substantially the educatonal attainment of many of these children, they do not bode well for the nation's future:

"Women with college degrees can be expected to complete their childbearing with 1.6-2.0 children each; 1.7 for non-Hispanic white, 1.6 for non-Hispanic black, and 2.0 for Hispanic women. For women with less education the total expected number of children are: 3.2 children for those with 0-8 years of education; 2.3 children for those with 9-11 years of education and 2.7 for high school graduates."

http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/pressroom/97facts/edu2birt.htm

Remember that these figures increase geometrically.

Kinda short on the remedy side. You say nothing about the anti-growth effects of recession-era fiscal conservatism, or about the hollowing-out of the economy that has occurred as a consequence of globalization.

Also, you don't address another problem: that the least educated among us are having the most kids, and that these children are in many cases not doing well in school. This may have the effect of increasing the percentage of unskilled laborers, who require precisely the jobs that are most likely to be lost to low-cost labor overseas.
Regulators don't need to act. The power already lies with consumers. All they have to do is to stop buying.

Content neutrality is going the way of net neutrality, business as usual, to the highest bidder. As others have pointed out, this will do nothing to benefit the end user, the consumer and the voter at large. The banks and law firms cited in the article's last paragraph will be laughing all the way to the Cayman Islands, if they can get there and back in time to carve up the brewing dispute in the domestic oil industry (described elsewhere in today's NYT). Commentator's observations about speed, price and choices compared to the rest of the world are the issues that should be first and foremost on the FCC's plate, that's their mandate. Thanks largely to the Supreme court, they don't have jurisdiction any more, at least over the internet. What do you expect from a court that sees "Here Comes Honey Boo Boo" as the free expression and exchange of ideas, and money as speech?

If this goes through, it may become the textbook case for multiple academic disciplines of rent-seeking behavior and regulatory capture.  There is no good public policy that can justify where this pushes the industry.  Instead of letting these titans distort and suppress the free-market for consumers, we should force them to de-bundle content and start offering channels a la carte, as we (for the moment) have on the Internet.  If not, the struggle for content-neutrality will only worsen as the media oligopolies change the Internet to a model that further cements their position.

I saw this comment late last night when it was still the only one. I had too much to say in response, so decided to wait until this morning. I'm glad to see that so many have so eloquently written many of my thoughts. I won't repeat them.

My one remaining observation is in regard to this statement regarding the effectiveness of hotlines: "This is one more reason that most people who die by suicide have had recent contact with so-called mental health services." Anyone with even a rudimentary understanding of statistics knows that this is irrelevant as a measure of hotlines' effectiveness.

What is relevant is: the number of people who called hotlines and did not commit suicide. The two are not the same thing.

hmmm... aek, you must be a Scientologist.  What is your response to all those who say they have been helped by a conversation on a hotline?   Are they delusional?  And if a person who was miserable is now able to deal with his feelings is helped by such a conversation, are you saying he is still miserable?

Important point you make.  For any hotline to pretend to be some kind of  cure-all would be irresponsible. I believe research does exist about hotlines but agree about outcomes being unmeasurable.   The point of the hotline isn't to 'solve' but to just be there, present, with the person in distress. No snake oil or false hope. (Maybe this depends upon the hotline, though?)

Those "crisis" hotlines are touted as legitimate places to call for help when there is no help. That is a lie. How many people act on unbearable psychache when they learn of this most unethical deception and suffer even more or act on that despair with suicide?

As you so aptly describe, the hotlines serve to salve the souls of the volunteers. There are no evidence-based standards of practice and no outcomes standards. Because after all, you can hang up at will.

This is one more reason that most people who die by suicide have had recent contact with so-called mental health services. They are snake oil, false hope deadly malarkey. And people in dire distress learn that fast and then face the reality that they are definitely on their own.

Shameful.

There is currently an increasing trend amongst young mainland Chinese that the Chinese communist regime is not exactly a legitimate regime. After all, it was not democratically elected and had practised tyranny against its people There is increasing feel the Chinese communist regime might collapse in few years to come, as the corruption and heavy-handed way in which it handled its democracy activist is getting too much dissent, to the point of overthrowing the regime. Majority of the mainland Chinese are now opposed to the Beijing regime and have grown to support the Republic of China regime in Taiwan. There is an increasing recognition that Republic of China (ROC) is the true democratic China and is the legitimate representative of "China" as it's democratically elected. The ideology that the Chinese communist regime will eventually collapse and Republic of China (from Taiwan) will retaking mainland China and eventually bringing a democratic reunification is increasingly being supported by mainland Chinese, Hongkongers and Taiwanese. In short, the Chinese wants freedom and democracy to mainland China, and feel that this is the right path: Abandon Chinese communist party and embrace Republic of China (ROC) is the way for China's future. It's time for US government to look at the legitimacy of Republic of China (ROC) government in Taiwan. Afterall, ROC remains a close democratic ally of the US.

Printing documents has nothing to do with having an individual desk/workspace. Mr. Wilkinson is completely off-base with his premise that desks are "based on people working with paper" and for storage only.

Desks are about having some semblance of individual space for work. Whether there's an "inbox" filled with sheets of paper on the desk or the desk's workspace is completely digital is irrelevant.

I worked at Barbarian for about two years. In that time I only printed out 3 documents: 1 presentation leave-behind, 1 travel document, and something else (I forget). The trick is that the entire organization is built around digital culture. It works, and it works well.
My thoughts exactly. This is for Type "A"s.

There are high areas for standing "desks," the spaces under the arches can serve as bookshelves - this short interview is just the tip of the iceberg of this particular project. This project was completed on a budget - and cost less than traditional desks would have, to have a custom-designed space with a desk built by robots. The wow factor perhaps sacrificed privacy and tradition, but this table is alive and can become whatever the organization wants it to, it flows and ebbs, like a stream. Interesting to see the fear and initial rejection by the public in this arena, Clive Wilkinson Architects are at the forefront of workspace design, and more experimentation has been completed with foreign clients, such as Macquarie Bank's One Shelley Street in Sydney, Australia and of course the predecessor to such a desk, Mother Advertising in London. Americans seem wary of taking such a chance on interesting design. The Barbarians are not normal, hence a quirky office that will likely work for them, only time will tell!

As a creative designer, I would be unable to tolerate such an office! I am neither a full extrovert, nor a full introvert, but need both social collaboration time as well as solitary time to really problem solve and explore creative concepts.

As a person who also prefers to NOT sit all day long, it does not look to have options for standing desks. I stand about 50% of my day, which has been proven as a most healthy alternative to sitting all day. And where do reference book go? And inspirational material, or my Wacom tablet, for that matter?

One more thing, as the lines between work life and personal life become blurred, as our hours in the office inevitably run past 8 a day, I find it rather presumptive that I would give up not only my personal time, but any modicum of privacy and personal space.

Highly conceptual designs are not always the most practical. But certainly very thought provoking!

There's a pit in every cherry and your comments are the pit in this one.  Let's remember, please, that Derek Jeter is not Barak Obama or John Boehner or Mitch McConnell, individuals whose acts have substantial impact on our daily lives.  He is a baseball player, an entertainer and a wonderful role model for all kids and more than a few adults, and little more, but the level at which he performed as a player and as a person is more than we have any right to expect from anyone.  To criticize his play with such "in-depth analysis" at this seminal moment in his career is just to simply miss the point of what baseball - and he - are all about.  Thank the Lord you are not on the Hall of Fame voting committee.

You need to watch White's catch again. It was a very good over the shoulder catch of a fly ball and would have been a triple play had Gruber not poorly executed the run down. Jeter's 1st base line running grab and perfect toss to Posada were very good athletic plays. What sets this play. in sum, apart is Jeter's presence of mind to be there to make the play. The short stop would normally be at second to make a play there on the batter who hit the ball down the right field line. This type of anticipation is all over his fielding career and is an intangible that few others possessed.  There is plenty of video to examine so, please, list 12 Ozzie plays that exceed the Oakland play. It was fun when he did flips between innings, this is true.

Are you kidding me? He is a 5 time gold glove at shortstop. How can you possibly argue his reputation is exaggerated? He will enter the Hall of Fame as a complete player who did it all. And with all of the nonsense that sometimes goes on in baseball he also has been dignified. Respected by his team mates and competitors. For me he embodies what I want to think about when I think about the Yankee tradition. Thank you Mr Jeter!!!

Jeter was a very good offensive player, and a very like-able player who performed with enthusiasm and flair.  But because he was a Yankee and played on the most expensive team in baseball, his reputation as a player is rather exaggerated.  The famous flip throw to home?  Really?  If anybody else had made that play, would it have become "iconic"?  Nowhere near as remarkable as, say, Devon White's miscalled triple-play for the Blue Jays against Atlanta in 1992, game 3, or any of a dozen plays by Ozzie Smith or Roberto Alomar.  And it was no secret that his defensive abilities-- which were not ever as exceptional as commonly thought-- had deteriorated significantly in the past five years.  Please, please don't do the nauseating "farewell tour" a la Cal Ripken.  Just leave with quiet dignity.  Never believe your own press.

Why do you bother to join this shared celebration of a great and genuinely heroic player with your admittedly ignorant comments? (Or do you merely pretend not to know who Jeter is?) Either way, one wonders if your contemptuous condescension is a symptom of some chronic gastrointestinal disturbance or perhaps something more psychiatric?

For what it's worth, Jeter comes from a family of educated professionals; his father earned a PhD at U of Michigan. A uniquely gifted athlete, Jeter signed with Yankees after a semester at U of Michigan, and came up to the majors about the time he would have been a college sophomore. An obvious leader from the start, he was named the Yankees' captain at age 28. He earlier announced post-retirement plans to become a book publisher, with his own imprint at Simon & Schuster. He has pursued his philanthropies quietly and devotedly since he first joined the Yankees.

Among athletes of all sports, Jeter is renowned as a model of integrity, professionalism, good manners, work ethic, and maturity. Your comment reflects decidedly different qualities.
